author: A_Brickset_user
review: The first decent technic car chassis. A rear mounted flat four cylinder engine drives the rear wheels through a 3-speed gearbox. Nice steering and adjustable seats, only the read wheels have suspension, however. Because this set was around before the customised parts really starting appearing, you could probably build it quite easily from a good selection of other sets. Overall, a very good early set.

author: A_Brickset_user
review: I was never into technic in a big way, but back in the 80's this just left me awestruck every time I walked into the shop that sold it. It comes in a nice box box and is definitely somewhere in my favourite top 5 technic sets.

author: A_Brickset_user
review: My goal is to collect all 5 "Super Car" sets that Lego has produced.  I had #956 and #8448 before I found this set on eBay.  It looked OK, but since I've built it, I've gained a new appreciation for it!  It was fun to build, fun to play with and was VERY easily motorized with the new 9V mini-motor.  I used an 8 tooth gear on the motor to a 24 tooth gear on the car's engine and only 6 other pieces to mount the motor. With this set-up, you get nice 3-speed action and no slippage or foul-ups.  What a great set!  Now, all I need is #8880 and #8865 to complete my collection.

author: A_Brickset_user
review: Why doesn't LEGO produce sets like this anymore? The techniques are quite simple, but you can use all parts for you MOCs! I have four of them, but I will buy a 5th copy when I see one at a reasonable price! One of my all time favorites!

author: A_Brickset_user
review:
Has my vote for the best Lego box ever; that box MAKES you want to buy it. When I was a little boy I drooled over this model in Lego catalogs.
Instructions make it easy to completely motorize the model (steering + transmission). The dragster alternate model is disappointing. For the best dragster, see the 8457 alternate model, which easily outshines the main model.

author: A_Brickset_user
review:
This set was fantastic in it's day, but has now been superceded by the 2 Super Car kits. I never really owned it but my friend did, so I used to regularly visit him for my building fix. Once we tried to make a body for the chassis, but rapidly ran out of bricks and couldn't get the scale right. The thing ended up looking like a Land Rover with tiny seats!
The 3 speed gearbox was a bit tricky to operate and the square engine pistons tended to jam in the cylinders and separate from the conn. rods, but all I have are good memories of this kit.
When I was a few years older my mother found a second hand version of this kit and gave it to my nephew. Unfortunately the kit was incomplete so we had to convert the car into a 3 wheeled version!!

author: A_Brickset_user
title: Good wine needs no bush
review: We in Hungary in the 80's just could have been dreaming of this technic set, I have just turned the leaves of the catalog with deep sighs. But now, after 20 years finally have got one copy. I've built it with deep sighs and I hold it of course in high respect. I hope so the LEGO someday will return to the origins.

author: A_Brickset_user
title: Superb
review: Had this set when it was new and am trying to buy a replacement for the one I sold with all my technic for forty pounds as a teenager. I rember the diff cogs used to pop off and the engine and gearbox used to separate from the rest of the car. I too tried (and failed) to build a body, my freind Chris had this set as well and we used to crash then down the stair so we could rebuild them and tried to build in extra strength, I also upgrade the motor to a six cylinder with Chris's model when he left it at my house !

author: A_Brickset_user
title: Ah, the memories
review:
This was my introduction to Lego Technic and I absolutely loved it. Many a moon base and space ship followed after. It's a great set, very educational, with working cylinders and crankshaft, three speed gearbox, steering, shock absorbers, the works. It even has adjustable seats!

I must have had a slightly different model though, because I see on the photo that it has regular axles with springs as shock absorbers, while my version has real spring-loaded one piece shock absorbers...

author: A_Brickset_user
title: Monster Car
review: The size of this car when finished just floored me.  This was the last technic set I ever bought.  I was getting old then.  Great set, although the image showed an old style shock system the set came with the updated shocks.  Plus the set also had a 'differential' for the drive axle.  Sweet!  4 big wheels, I was in heaven. :)  Takes a while to make but end result is well worth it.

author: A_Brickset_user
title: Truest technic essence
review:
The 8860 improved on the wonderful 853 (a differential! shock absorbers! 3-speed transmission!), and has satisfyingly stout construction. Over the years I have whiled away many good hours of building with this set.

I bought my 8860 while visiting Legoland in Denmark in 1981. My parents told me to wait until we returned home to build the kit. By the time we got home, I had managed to surreptitiously build the 8860's seats without losing any parts or getting caught. 

About 20 years ago, I spent a day building a car body for my 8860 out of non-technic pieces, and the housecat pulled it off the table about five minutes after I finished it. Pieces went everywhere, but none of them were broken. I have since forgiven the cat.

10/10, 1 April 2004

author: A_Brickset_user
title: the best lego kit i ever owened
review:
in 1980 i was bought this kit by my parents for my birthday and still have it among others in my loft waighting to give the same plesure to my kids one day. im 32 now and i think this kit should be re released.
Matt Roberts

author: mattressnz
title: Fond memories.
review: Received this for my 9th birthday and it took me all day to build it (included a right hand drive conversion!) An absolute classic. Unfortunatley some of the parts have fallen victim to the vacume cleaner but most of them are still available.

author: Time4TT
title: The second car chassis
review:
A marvelous improvement on the original Lego car chassis (853). This model fixed all the problem with the original (it didn't sag under it's own weight, included a differential gear and worked well in all it's gears).

This model shifted the engine to the rear - VW Bug fashion - and included suspension on the rear. It didn't quite work here as the wheels angled up & in (instead of just going up), but overall a big improvement on the original model (which had fake suspension legs which didn't do much except fall off).

The only other problem I remember is the seats would tend to fall flat when used as the ratchet gear got a little loose. However, a great evolution from the original.

author: hustla187
title: Do I Need to Say More?
review: This is one of the best Technic sets ever made. The car chassis is very cool in every single way possible. Also, if you have enough pieces, you can make the exterior of the car which would look awesome. The engine is very detailed too. If you had only two Technic sets, this should be one of them.

author: Pedro_Abrantes_dos_Santos
title: Uma revolução para época.
review:
Esperiência construtiva:

Um ótimo desafio costrutivo, garantindo horas de boa diversão. A caixa de mudanças foi sem dúvida o mais complicado de ajustar.

Peças:

Incrível trabalho deste projetista neste SET. Muito bom o que ele fez com a limitação da variedade de peças.

Jogabilidade:

Depois de pronto tem um visual muito atraente e as cores ajudam a entender cada parte funcional do veículo.

Valor:

Seu custo não é dos mais caros, se levar em consideração o tamanho que fica montado. Sem dúvida tem presença.

author: vuldalm
title: All time best...
review:
Is this the ultimate Lego Technic Car?

I still have this model boxed with instructions etc and it must have been disassembled for nearly twenty years!

When it was fully constructed I modded it the infinate degree.  I installed a backseat, a third gear, reverse gear, twin carburetors, modified the steering, seats, fitted a centre console and even...wait for it...carpets.

The ultimate aim was to create a "rolling" road to test the models endurance on but I never quite got there before other hobbies, and girls, came along.

One fine weekend I'm sure I will put this back together and then warn the rest of the family not to touch ot play with it while I admire it it!

author: stux
title: 2nd Super Car
review:
I've been collecting and building the Technic Super Cars. I'm built up to 8880.

853, the previous car is a fantastic super car, 8860 is the bridge between this and 8865.

These are the three Super Cars with brick built engines.

8860 was the Supercar that I always saw in the catalogs as a child, and was then replaced by 8865.

8860 Has an awesome steering linkage, which is brickbuilt.

First Supercar with the true Differential and Shock Absorber.

It also is the first Supercar with an attempt at suspension, but the brickbuilt rear suspension is far far better in 8865 although based on the same technology (the technic shock absorber)

Biggest weak point is that a few features are only connected by one or two studs and tend to fall off very easily. The seat ratchets, although clever, tend to collapse easily.

The engine is fun, and the gears work very well for an unsynchronized gear box. Much better than 853, and possibly more fun than 8865 too. Low gear makes a good engine sound and high gear is very smooth. 

I especially like the fan belt, although when the belt falls into the engine its a royal pain to fix.

I actually had a cog misalign in the engine recently and the whole thing exploded necessitating an engine rebuild!! (very realistic ;))

A fun build, but I do prefer both 853 and 8865.

853 is beautiful in its simplicity and system/technic hybridness, and 8865 is the culmination of the brick-built engine supercars, adding new parts for steered suspension, and the outline of a body.

8860 is a nice car, and it is fun to play with, and its very obviously the missing link between the two...

It seems to be my 10 month old daughter's favourite (maybe because she can break it so easily ;))

Its essentially a beach buggy

Now, I'm off to build 8448 ;)

author: Bart_66
title: last set
review: After getting my first set in 1972,this was my last lego set as a kid.I bought it with my own money when i was 14 years the year it came out,it was 114 guilders and i remember the price increased 10 guilders each year after that.I loved the technic sets.20 years later I started buying technic set for our own kids.

author: TechnicNick
title: The Ultimate in Early Technic
review:
A useful update of the 853 (fixing that car's flaws), the 8860 really was the ultimate in 80s Lego. Featuring a smooth running engine with some very nice detailing, a clever little ratchet mechanism to recline the seats and swing axle rear suspension, this robustly constructed car brought many hours of fun.

I still much prefer it to the awkward-looking later 8865.

The only thing this set lacks is a convincing 2nd model - odd when you consider all the things this very complete collection of parts makes possible.

It's easy to update too - adding front suspension wasn't hard (even without the later ball joints it's possible - but it's better if you have them) and, thanks to the low first gear, it runs well with the period motor. Just don't ask this to propel it in the highest gear..

If you're interested, you can see what I've inflicted on this car here :

http://www.mocpages.com/moc.php/275626

If you only ever get one technic set, make it this one. A timeless classic.

author: homosporocarpus
title: the ultimate set of the time
review: only recently have i realised how lucky and privileged i was having this set as a child and having been given the opportunity to build, expand, experiment thanks to it. this is the kind of ‘toy’ that later define your choices, your creativity and mind-set in a broader sense. one can only wonder, but i’d bet an arm that the amount of new neural connections in my brain that have grown as a result of the mental processes involved in the play would be significant. :)
